zero:stanza.zero:line: The kid speaks in pages. He sees only what's visible written of him:
the difference that splits collier and collider. Black on black.
Widening rings: his days on buses, trains—he listens for want:
something better to do, a left-hand side capacity to hold.
These make stories of everywhere headed south:
the conversation topics of Utah backpackers, whether they're
nameplated, contrast shifted to magpie black and white;
pinafores hovered on newsstands stacked with watchtowers
(blue square logo so up to the minute),
and the ones he likes—saffron & galangal pink, he gets them
off context: still with a smell of rose petals giving way to weed
lifted from lakebeds, digested by swans.
The kid's heard them (Hare Rama) in the city's interstices and to no one
in particular under this particular swamp cypress: odd for a conifer:
forked up its trunk and a tiger iron pedicure: planted for AC Bhaktivedanta—
become time; his step fossils in red & gold stone.
The kid likes the percussion and its goddesses: less stolen bone
than one or another temperature of breath blown fast or slow.
Appeal and heal are one thing between here and the river:
the ones that bug him most thinking in clay: his twisted
or their perception sounds like an off concept of perfection
—a wishing in mirrors for miracles.
Reflection illumines the recruiter, he thinks,
and wonders whether vampires can be seen in selfies.
The kid dreams of the sea—blank and grey off a coast where Graham
sounds like gram not gramme—the waves in his ears a dubplate of white
noise and exclusive-or. He dreams the wrong kind of seagull:
silver Croicocephalus, red feet and a voice of ring modulated
wanting. The gull fumbles through systems of casting-off:
basking shark mouthed bins hidden in drifts of seaweed;
leafless spiral bindings—shreds of half circle perforation
remaindered in the helix; wad of unmoored sticky notes.
Other gulls clustered between crests; how they whorl
the water under downdraft, make their own overtone
transverse to the surface. It occurs at the limits of system thinking—
between synapse, gyre, reflection, deviations of wave reduced to noise
and maybe subatomic possibilities exist somewhere else
but, whatever, nobody knows and the kid suspects the theorists
clink vodka shots with knowledge it's beyond observation
so there's nothing to lose, no quantum suicides in the papers;
a list of inexplicable—why Steep Hills of Vicodin Tears
gets stars on its shoulders; why a poem—collision of astrophysics
and distance—gets its distribution; who can rock the dude-
with-pood look down the park; who can't and decants.
Back to that question of coalminer and CERN. Serve eggs boson
for breakfast all you like, you can't quark pools faster than light;
the clock's wrong somewhere between Switzerland and Italy. There's a story
in that north: true or magnetic, believing blind—fewer or less are buying it;
in the dream the man speaks in a coat (either black or white)
in black and white—the kid can't catch the crest of wave function collapse;
the cat in the box long-haired or short, coal or magnesium salt:
a difference between crow and gull—white eyes either way
so colour's all the same in the end—who do we kid
with questions of lemma & toyota corollary?
a serious car, the coronary, and will it get bogged if seeing
isn't believing, if a road's only narrow bridges and cold shoulders?
cars for the shifting of I think, a white environment for ideas.
how warm they remain—when they call the movers and why—
there's no stroking the kitten with isotope and poison pill
but its story's bound; same goes for dogs, gods, supermassive black holes.
A mirror's glass on one side of silver: it's EMR whoever's cut
and it gives itself the same to retina, CCD, photo-chemical filament:
the difference between diffraction and pigment doesn't result
in non-peacock, or something other than fairy wren.
The kid isn't sure if this story ever happened—remembers the street
and the two dollar shop he worked in; his mum says this all happened
and he thinks of the people he sees there: small package
of man with a face that places him from everywhere: Japan, Mexico,
Whadjuk Country; he camps by bus stops camouflaged in silver streaked beard,
heaped cloth on box after box of belongings. The kid wonders how this comma
of bone and hair gets his cardboard parlour from block to block and what the other
man says under his breath: hard shell headphones (he guesses) keep unbidden
orators out (somewhat) and the kid thinks it's odd that at volume he's
incomprehensible; passed close once, heard his history in eighties Australian politics:
Hawke, Bond, Rothwells all pinned under his breath. The one he called
street preacher: volume better but never enough for traffic, for weekdays,
for strength of character or the gravelly skin white on his fingers. Correlation (inverse
or otherwise) of volume and grammar never a question with the one he called
dervish: silence and seasons always the same: beachwear at his ankles, fleece cowl;
always walking, walking. The kid's never seen these men swipe a slab of black glass—
or the woman with pigeons in cat carriers—the kid thinks it's a different
map that way, pictures the transition between Mercator and its transverse:
the moment the earth takes curvature: how it's hidden until the fresh coat
of satellite tiles, hidden from these sleeping on asphalt and powerless battery.
That street, it's this he remembers: right leg bent and his sole against layers
of paste, paint, poster paper: Rizla and Drum keep cost in inverse
proportion to dopamine; a vague twist of off-white Nikes and the old
lady's shoulder drops; she pitches left and half steps to stay up;
and after the kid's steps are ouroboric, tail-recursive; cycle of contact
and non- and at speed the kid doesn't see the slate grey patter
of chewing gum and shoe dust, the black savannah on his left shoulder.
He passes cheap sushi and unbelievable deals on overseas calls, spears right
into the black valley of margin vs volume: mannequins wrapped in tapped aquifer
and public sculpture doubles as seating, k-grind, and however the kid thinks back now:
the red sea press of oxygen breaching his bloodstream; a half-baked kind of elevation
on herringbone slabs; weird hearing cliché in his voice and no response:
from fear, IFF failure, or slow cognition of shoppers he never found out,
left instead with the differing moments of other men and a crazed relationship with theft:
wonders about birritt under blacktop: who holds story and the oxidation states of iron:
its shift from red to black with gash, pavement, hours. Not today, though,
he flows under bridges as if split between aquine and equine, horse and water,
assemblage of legs and surface tension. Altogether, the kid didn't see more
than half a mouth fixed open, wide eye and blonde shock raked across gravity;
didn't cinch the distance and only stopped to pick up dropped belongings.
The kid thinks perhaps it happened: his mum has a story: an Instagram
screenshot—He just fuckin chased a dude who stole a woman's bag —that phone long gone
to wherever phones go (mythical land of bromide, Li-ion, cadmium)
and the image silted under years, lost amongst some quadrillion pixels.
the kid dreams of himself and a sister: her face the same
as an elfin actress whose name he won't remember when he wakes
and their connection label-deep. She's thin, red teeth and white
fabric at her hip shifts under his touch, retakes its place like satin
but he sees an off angle in its bias—streak of grey from hip to hem
and he's headed away with his dad (a face made from scratch)
while the room is packed and late day sunlight
woodgrains voices, talk about new books: plotlines just beyond
his capacity to maintain faith or a background in physics—moments
of force a mystery, let alone general relativity; doesn't know the kind of tree
let alone the episode of brother-shovel bludgeoning.
In amongst this the kid hears his mother's voice,
turns past the vase of regret-me-nots. The late day sunlight's
backward: it has mass and no momentum;
his mother left there in its yellowing, faced away palms flat at the table
and her hair's dark horizon, a width of sunset above muslin—
white cloth stretched now on hollow bones
and turned on her left ankle; the kid left to wonder if the right
foot's missing, and when she rests on top of the wind the left tucks
under and he hears the squall in her voice: descent and modulation.
And In times of plague, it is forbidden to spit at cats whatever condition their hip,
but what happens when the kid thinks of his mum? love must propagate
at greater than 300,000 ks a second; otherwise the guy riding the c train,
he lobs an orange forward and his wife's forbidden to think of him.
Dreams of dad and sister—superposition of stranger and familiar:
the kid wonders why seagulls sound different in movies: Hitchcock's
made of mixtur-trautonium; cries wheeled through wide arcs on
European updrafts, far from the kid's winterless city: too lost to feel at home
and maybe the city fishes for a kind of hydrophobic Moses—fogs its breath
between concrete and glass mangroves, rifles mounds of red check
blanket, stacked plastic takeaway containers—comes bucket hatted,
lectures twentieth century politics under its breath
by the Tiergarten-twinned crier. The kid thinks, or will, is this his real dad
while asleep; what it means to kiss his dream-sister and where love goes
when the recipient's fictional—out to clouds over oceans,
its vector stripped of direction. The kid feels his skin ruffled,
pushed in a fresh gust of moments he feels the hair on his limbs
as a weight of white fabric, the temperature drop in evening air.
He knows now how to hold this eigenvalue of affection;
scale asphalt streams and remember waking.
The kid pictures what these streets feel before his time—
hard plastic buckets passed for seats at school, the kid's history
teacher's laugh once (4G sluggish through old ferroconcrete):
her day: a beige handset to talk and a meeting took days to affect—
streets shorn: his diminished ability for lostness, history wikiform now
and friends' everpresence: a cognition of whatever this font is and felines.
The kid thinks what colour a fairy wren would be without the screen
of code division multiple access sheened over light poles—
a blue, he thinks, as if it's raven to asphalt: a brighter, higher saturation
black—the kids here'd scavenge colour from wheelie bins, jacaranda
flowers and motor oil rainbows in first rains; run fingers
in the wind to listen at beige painted front doors, all the streets' numbers
in stainless steel, oxide blemished at their edges: digits curled in heat and blanched
under a crust of salt and old age. Stall all the nodes, the kid calls to himself:
calls for silence in a forest of squat altars to the union of fibreoptic and copper,
where an easterly yellows lawn and shed computer carapace sounds the sea,
tide line littered with toner shells, OLED boxes, IKEA beast's withered bones.
Beachcombers come in vans with blank black rimmed eyes; creatures
peer out beneath the clay tile breakers and galvanised waves—
give them the welcome you'd get for spoonbenders at funerals;
brighter than you'd think where sun doesn't reach
and seasons wash over unnoticed: spring, winter, The West Wing,
and always bled through the edge of metaphor, these seagulls.
The kid tries to think where he's seen them; hasn't been to the beach.
The kid thinks of the river, the stretch where it lies back; no rush to the ocean,
thinks where the line lies between river and sea: possibly salt or where the gulls won't go;
they beg for fish & chips the same either way and water's equally clear
upstream where potatoes begin their flow, take measure of rain, river;
let salt and vinegar follow where seagulls and grease traps meet
in the neverending car wreck of canola, revenant forest burned below decks
and the kid thinks if it's always been there for seeing—that fish & chips
come from somewhere other than the shopfront and Mediterranean name,
(and what's Mediterranean anyway but a Tolkienesque way of saying
the whole radiates from here), and what if it doesn't belong in a place
where the topsoil's as thin as silence, a collection of yesterdays struggling
for sunlight like a family of cats in a box (white cats more often deaf).
The kid's been on the end of that anger: split lip and an hour late to school,
hidden in a rosemary hedge; started to think (now he's been dragged over doorways
for locked-on muscles down his left, as if drunk or overdone witchcraft)
that unvoiced stories make for collapsed wave functions: dead futures
for ghosts of yesterdays: the Erwin Schrödinger thing shows that cats sat in boxes
long before can has, perhaps that only—the kid thinks of the ethics, then, of observation:
how much to insure against wave function collapse, the end of a present,
what the actuaries can check—the actual fuck—whether there's claim for act of god.
The kid knows now it's no lowland holiday: this language moved from his head
to his hand; remembers it small and coiled in his prefrontal cortex
—or that's how it felt—tight behind his eyes and pressed against slow bone.
language would pine for outside, backlit plane where mechanics are frictionless.
He starts to see (language in his hand now) which machine he'd shaped:
used to think of his CPU, an aluminium and silicon millipede needed obedience
training—he'd bark in unspoken tongues with no word for consequence or pocketful
of treats. And it's him, he sees, that salivates at the sound of exclusive or
and begun to see in algorithm, the city in VLSI: A* finds the fastest path
from screen to biological imperative, each street's a switching code
for whichever function he needs—north bridge for pictures, memory;
south for outside—the kid keeps cyclomatic complexity low, never crosses routes;
never mixes strips of asphalt. Today he takes his fifty-sixth route on the left, the path
to Pasquale's: treads with care at the driveway: he's down to seventeen nanometres
between routes out of the house; a miniscule slip could pitch him hours south and east:
once there he's carnelian and Carnaby's: red tail trail cakes his shoes and won't shake loose.
Steps slow, the kid inches out and thinks his friend's handle: picked for a favourite way in:
some say ess-cue-ell-eye, others sequel-eye. The friend says he's a storm's eye, likes it squally.
pasqli squats on a cheap office chair—backrest sneezes brominated foam
and doesn't lift from minimum position—quizzes code wired and never asks one question
at once. pasqli's grin spins counter-clockwise within his cardioid pattern of silver wrappings—
pop tart pupae; Nicorette foil. The kid asks a new path: tells pasqli he'd walked the causeway
25-1 exits west of the track that took him to school (kept open and unused), the road
over artificial anabranch—long land filled and given back to the river: a garbage Manhattan.
Sunk in sheoak needles, sun dipped beneath the treeline, the kid clapped at mosquitos in air
grey with ground out wattle bird conversation: djiti-djiti visible but overpowered. shoes
on blue aggregate, chin on his shoulder, he checked back on his path and she'd stood
with her hand at his elbow, wolf in blue ink springing from her wrist. —these
were called condil, you understand why they gather—who—you hear them speak
their necks red—them—yes. that language, listen, has words for hearing—i—listen
louder—will say what you've forgotten—. pasqli ticks in his yellow foam halo. —got
your laptop—yep—ok—. checks the pockets in his coat of mathematics: power
and modulo, folded tickets of hops through city block ciphers. sixteen languages
between pasqli's keys and the city's systems; two need speaking. pasqli works blind:
trades voltage for time; says tell me about trees and escape' where one equals zero;
sleep(5); black enter clicks and pasqli's watch—grids mocked in monospace
freeze from black and the shapes of plan, order, approval—filings for a fresh centimetre;
new nand gates for navigation: the blue wolf's house, hand at his elbow. The kid's route home
stays the same as always: left where the white terrier warns against trespass, he steps
on pavers' hard right. This stretch crosses the path to his mum's and he stops:
the kid's wish to be wavelike; to cross concrete at odds with his system: a knowing
how many nanometres between here and awake. The kid turns into his street,
between boxes he sees one edge of the city—tower glass slate in sundown light.
The man in tangerine to ankle and wrist folds away pedestrians watch your step, stripes
fine the light from seams on his uniform, from traffic cones' chords, galvanised
in black counters on the a-frame folded, placed back in the aluminium tray, pale grey flat
in low-pressure sodium light. The kid steps across his body to set feet in line—
each millimetre either side keeps its own logic—steps sideways at his gate to stay on thread.
The kid begins again—what if this grounding weren't given an overlay,
but how sad is land shorn of narrative; thinks for new kinds of finding:
song for CDMA, ley for TCP and voice for satmap tile—
they replace heat haze and air (always absent on a Google map);
the kid isn't sure how boundaries of federation and old war
will show, isn't convinced it'll matter: everyone hunts in Venn diagrams
anyway: the courier, kookaburra, cat; thinks it odd what comes from the cloud
has stiff edges and thinks of overlaid ghosts—political map and Gondwanaland,
and anyway there's an end to what happens when maps run down scale ratios—
the story has cartography compost under its referent and maybe the paper
these days is all Scalable Vector or wavelet compression—one-to-one sugar gums
as old as the colony and still too small for story. Pinch for big picture.
The kid thinks at the deckled edge of space—if coastlines approach infinite distance
where borders skirt sand grains and when: paint blue if its submerging's permanent;
beige for solid sand at any tide—no thinks the kid, a map has to have scales for distance,
viscosity; for a sense of wetness at the back of a hand and pasts without written language
or colour code; imagines schematics for GIS: fear for getting lost, for missed
plans; anything else a kind of wrong-scale proprioception, orientation & origin
when nothing's cartesian—centres are everywhere and this, the kid thinks,
is a way to greet a friend in the ground, to disinter on an older timescale.
Satmap mosaic has red tracks; never cold days and rain to wash clay pale
back into winter for coat after coat: old wood eaten from its middle
and nailed labels into stone—the line splits dolerite from granite,
one grey pixel from the next in UTM projection and however many million years.
The kid thinks of equivalent time scales: his mum's shown him the books
in old newsagents (stately logo from the eighties), told him of her mum
and a perfect bound perception of the city: UBD always missing new streets,
clear vinyl case lost in a floor well and white string adrift on its spine.
The kid thinks of equivalent time scales: three days with screen splinters,
no credit, SOS Only—a list of conditions he striates time with, some pushed
into the page: his walking transient to analogue: slices of time from which he overlooks
whatever comes before; this is his angle of incidence.
The kid thinks of equivalent time scales, old folks' homes:
big doors for furniture, for passing; hollow bones and frictionless hinges;
doors to fit tomorrows where the kid's this is rose-tinted and Zimmer assisted:
golden age for climate action, everyone fed and respected.
He thinks of a square on a calendar somewhere, as yet unprinted, unexed,
a fix for his broken proprioception, the set of accelerometers
embedded or wedged in his pocket. The kid thinks the trade isn't zero sum
(or even close) but won't know the cost until its deduction.
The kid considers whichever face in the mirror as if he's some kind
of slightly different future; red eyed like a box-sealed seagull:
isotope, poison gas, concentric shells of observation and his wave
function slowly collapsed between there and somewhere zero distance away;
half the face more relaxed on an axis, more relaxed than it ought to be
anyway, and to rinse the face and return to bed would be a comfort to think except
that's how it starts: to lose a self in the looking, walk without maps
and there's always accounting where mothers are involved.
The kid thinks his species of lost has a different name:
turns his face as if its shape's the same and elevation's changed
or a short war's drawn a line of foreign politics; perhaps a long one;
the kid brings his lips back against his teeth and breathes through force:
a spread of stubbled topsoil and the wrong side myoclonic in reflection.
He shuts his eyes and feels like a chart of pandemic spread with a zero
height y axis: origin everywhere and all the nations' names overlaid,
pinched until the city's the size of a pixel: the right green and dry, left all at sea.
The kid thinks of the day he saw his mum at the demo—his girlfriend had
taken him—the kid thinks this is the day he'd drawn a winter oak
high on her thigh, his mum had found its mirror in black leatherette
against their dining table, wondered if it were a sign and of what,
it'd sat that way all night and nobody touched it, his girlfriend emerged
in cold morning sun; tree-drawn and sleep-ruffled. His mum could never guess
what pencil made the branches and their echo, both the colour of ghost.
The kid no longer remembers, guesses this memory is in the house
that looked over a floodplain: samphire flared red every May with the heavy
smell of sunk—the kid could never resist the white crystalline trails, crusted
before footfall as if to say the place was solid, safe, and a mass of black streaks
where he'd left his balance. The kid thinks it's that house, that morning—a smell
connects the house and its garage, a sound of seagull calls. Except the kid finds the sound
slippery in his mind, remembered or manufactured he isn't clear, called from across the blue
line where the people of dream still skirmish with old conquerors, and the kid thinks
perhaps that house was too far upstream; all water fowl, or rainbow bee-eater on good days,
the path down to flats coincident with concrete columns, cardboard placards: primary
colours fuzzed at their edges. The kid remembers backs, asphalt between however
many feet; a still image before blinking—mouth open in profile, eyes angled upward
at free air and bedsheet banner. A still image before walking forward—
the kid isn't sure how many colours he'd used for the koi tail he sprayed
on the cops' car: he counts out in his head: five shades in its spots (not counting white)
alone and wonders how he'd had that many cans. Tags on the buildings simpler,
black and he feels a twinge for the bricks' biscuit surface—the colour of thigh-branch.
There's the day the kid asked what the crowd were angry about: a shoeprint solidity
in details listed from memory: forest green cotton in cylinders ending a woman's dreads;
her face and its terrain—fault and topography. The kid remembers all kinds of acrylic on card:
climate strike, black lives, can't place what the placards said that day, and no-one remembers
the police car's koi panels, his girlfriend's tattoo jet black fresh on her scapula: oxbow curve
and Möbius topology of a narrow-headed snake; measure of venom in its tail; no-one
remembers a spray-can bandolier—the day's thread pulled loose from its selvedge and shifts
in crosshatch across memory: the different pitch of before and after; yesterday's moiré.
Maybe AC gets it on the moors, AC on the edge of desert. Both ways
are ok as long as the kid thinks in irreducible difference: one and zero:
AC's plague the sickness from within: rats under asphalt, flowers under
ice pools' thaw: Law and the other AC lacking a Brontëoid immunity, a serum
against anything shifting at greater than 300 thousand ks a second.
No such thing, but there's always meth, fluoxetine, eight hour days, TV;
left to wonder which AC is coolest: Bhaktivedanta, Carson, or Camus.
Could even be Chekov, Clarke, that Crowley nut; but Carter always a fave:
so much blood, so much blue hair. Nobody knew substitutes for love
better than that character—his little key, her giveaway. No privileged upbringing,
the kid thinks of someone he's seen on the streets: thonged and hood open
to asphalt, how he walks unseen between beat cops and geek orthodox priests:
his different occupation of space: face made of machine learning:
neuron and loss function. A recombinant net retrodicting an alien landscape,
that one finds a way through space with a map of nowhere except where he is,
where he treads on a dead sea of electromagnetism: concrete footpaths
laid long form and bevelled, seamed to seem as slabs; pavers cast upside
down and aggregate sunk blue to pale faces. The kid's seen office workers
on the same pavers: shoulders around their jowls and the jealous glares
at the passerines in street trees: wattle birds, lorikeets, the habitats of Carnaby's:
there's—land as manifold. The kid doesn't think this, what kind of colour infills
a frame; how it's numbered: Pantone or hexadecimal (CMYK, RGB, HSB)
anyway not the same as satmap or world political Mercator, street map, postage
stamp. The manifold asks where here is, and when: how wide is scale, a count of terms
and how we come to them, recoded colour over time: redshifted leaves under plane
trees, swamp cypress, and how long it takes ex-Soviet nations to flower. And that's where
the kid thinks: in how wide-voiced the chord of sunflower, oak, Crimea. A shift
of perception in cycles of twenty-four, three-hundred-sixty-five, ten; how to address
that memory on the network—forget the machine and let the machine forget: the kid's
brain as cache and conduit for what's in the cloud and a map of bigger things:
a catalogue of places outside existence. The kid wonders if the seagulls make the same
sound between ticks of the clock when states' borders change, when magnetic north drifts
on its figure of eight and twists the map—fingers down and a flex of tendon.
If there's a lesser modulation on their breath without sunlight: those black fantails:
the kid gets why they're called djiti-djiti but only in daylight; the song from the box
trees on black streets needs another name, a name that takes longer to say at solstice.
The kid never obsessed for mathematics: thinks of it as language where everything's
indefinite pronoun: its blades shear away names, everything from the kid's to Latin binomial,
instead got his physics from wood and bearing: shuv and kickflip for medial axis theorem,
his one hundred eighty times table; how numbers' mass irons the lines from space.
No longer ok on uneven terrain, the kid's given up on old quarries—cuts flushed
with oxidation states of iron: red and black splitting grevillea thickets as sun dews
on the city quilted below. Once, an odd white light on the horizon line: sun-bright,
rain and dust a rug shaken out between the kid and it; a warp of not knowing reflected
sun from artificial: an Airbus beneath him, a swim in black and red cuts in stone:
once somebody's job and sprayed over with postcodes: 6108, 6071, 6003. Another way
to quantise country, to grid the granite—a good year it pulses green to black: subpixel
that winks out feeding lichen, sundew, grevillea and New Holland Honeyeater; the whole
thing: a loss of productivity. Back then, in the hills, the kid couldn't figure out the lines of it,
its striation—how that white light might look from a parallax angle and how straight
the 33kVs from flown overhead, missing the misdirection of topography. Reduced
to powers of two: Mersenne primes, perfect numbers, how to use them.
The kid wonders how far he pokes out into rivers of future, past—thinks of a self
as swamp cypress, knees on their banks, a line with odd polyrhythm and this his ascender
of grounding; one side of posture locked on, and everything reddens before a fall.
